I can't help but notice that your MIG is set incorrectly. It shouldn't spit like that. Try tuning your amperage and wire speed. It should sound like sizzling bacon, not crackling. Once you get it set right, your welds will be much nicer and won't leave porosity.

From a sad, rusty old hulk, to a perfectly painted and polished beauty! I can't wait to start my first real restoration, even though I have 3 other hobbies. I'm afraid a few of them may have to go! One of them, though, is just a very occasional thing I probably wont do but a few more times, which is refurbishing/restoring old bikes.

I looked at his sad coffee grinder and I said "yeah, we can do better". Again, nice job. I have an old stand-up ash tray waiting to be saved. The bottom is pretty rough, but some autobody putty (Bondo) will help, nicely. I need to learn some basic tig and mig welding and machining on a machinist's lathe (engine lathe?). Do lots of those parts on your refurbishments need to be mirror polished? Fifteen hundred to 2K grit is just fine, also in some instances. Do you wet-sand your primer with 2K or lower? 1,500?

I was a little disappointed you didn't make an effort to deepen the surfaces on the milling part of the grinder but the ground size in the tray at the end looked very good.  Terrific restoration again.  You are a master sir.  Just one more suggestion...all parts that may come in contact with food should be finished with walnut oil, not linseed.  In an enclosed space like the drawer, the linseed oil smell will linger for a long time.  It will not be toxic because it never comes in contact with the coffee but it will smell.  Walnut is a natural, food grade oil that dries.  Never use mineral oil or vegetable.  They never dry and become very dirty and eventually rancid.

Ideally, the grinding parts would be made out of tungsten carbide, and you'd never have to worry about rust or dulling. A suitable grade of stainless steel would work too. As for keeping the original carbon steel parts, the only thing that would keep it rust-free while leaving it dry is plating it. Industrial hard chrome for example, would last forever. Tinning it would be the easiest and cheapest thing to do, but that wouldn't be anywhere near as durable as hard chrome. I suppose you could oil-blacken the parts, but that would probably wear off quickly.

Excellent restoration and attention to fine detail! Love the copper rivets and the brass fasteners used in the handle. One word of wisdom, avoid using olive oil as a rust preventative. If you must use it, use extra virgin olive oil. It has the lowest acid content. Yes olive oil does contain acid. The lower the acid content the higher quality oil. I have seen the net results of what was left of confiscated German machine guns that partisan fighters tried storing in vats of olive oil to keep them safe from rust and from the governments that formed after the war. Most steel firearms were rusted beyond repair. The best lubricant to use around food equipment to guard against rust is a silicone lubricant that is used on soft serve ice cream makers. It should be available on Amazon.

Don't use olive oil to lubricate! It is NOT good for lubricating food prep! It will go rancid. We don't oil cutting boards with olive or other food oils. You need a food grade mineral oil or Camilla oil. Look for it in a hardware or grocery store. That olive oil will be rancid within a month and give the coffee nasty flavors and odors. The food based oils are high in unsaturated fats, which have double and triple bonds that break easily to oxidize. This makes them easy for your body to manipulate and break down, but makes them garbage for lubricating food prep equipment

Impressive! There is something that is indescribable about restoring antiquated objects. When I am doing something like that, I am almost communicating with the people who originally made / assembled / designed. I restored a Chatule, box to hold cutlery, from 1820. The inside cloth was almost vaporized and the outside wood was almost black. However, the silk flannel was preserved with the logo embossed in gold. It took me almost a year to restore it into the original condition. It was quite a big box to hold 198 pieces of cutlery in 3 shelves / trays. It had a base with four legs. I showed it to an Antiquarian. He appraised it to be from 1820. He also confirmed that it was made for King, Oscar 1 of Sweden. He also advised me to put it at the State Auction. The highest bid was the equivalent of £10,000. My wife, a Swede, and our daughter, were there. It was a moment that I shall never forget. My daughter, a precocious 13, stopped the bidding and withdrew. She is 37 now. Yep, we still have it. It is filled with my wife's family heirloom, yes, 198 pieces of silver cutlery from 1893 onward. Each time I look at it, I reminisce my year spent on restoration. I am going to be 80 in June. I wonder who shall be next to restore it. Yes, my friend, restoring is unique and it has its own rewards. Money loses its value.

When I saw how much material was missing from the 2 parts which make contact w/each other during the "grinding" process, I wondered what they were made of. I also wondered...where'd the "missing material" go  ;)  AND if a magnet would have any affect on it. I ask b/c if it does respond to magnet, it would be interesting to see [given there was a suitable mounting situation i.e. bottom of the drawer] how much material it would collect over any given period of time. ..BTW, well done.  (:{I>

Great restoration as always but... you didn't fix the most important part: the grinding mechanism. It's all dulled. This thing will not give you a good grind, it wil just break your beans by pressure which will put stress on the metal and damage it even further and give you an uneven grind. A grinder actually cuts the beans.

If you don't actually plan on using it and just want it to look good then this build is complete, but if you actually want to use this in any capacity to grind coffee, you need to sharpen every little blade of this mechanism, maybe even remake a new one since it's really busted up.
